Course Description: Finance is, in a real sense, the corner stone of the enterprise system – good financial management is vitally important to the economic health of all firms and hence to the nation and the world. Because of its importance, finance should be widely and thoroughly understood. The field is complex and it undergoes constant change due to shift in economic conditions. All of this makes finance stimulating and exciting, but challenging and sometimes perplexing. This course aims at creating a better understanding of the financial system.

Course Outcomes.CO1: Understand the ideas behind the time value of money and be able to calculate the value of cash flows relating to a number of financial instruments
Course Outcomes.CO2: Create and interpret financial and cash flow statements
Course Outcomes.CO3: Demonstrate proficiency in valuation techniques, both DCF (discounted cash flow) and non-DCF
Course Outcomes.CO4: Have a framework for analysing the major types of financial decisions made by corporations.

Weekly Lecture Plan.Lecture Topic: Elements of Balance Sheet, Income statement and Cash Flow Statements

Weekly Lecture Plan.Assignments: Analysis of a Financial Statements of a company and comparing ratios with the industry average

Resource Material.Textbook: Fundamentals of Financial Management (13th edition); Brigham Eugene F, Houston Joel F. Cengage Learning
Resource Material.Reference Book: Fundamentals of Financial Management (13th edition); Brigham Eugene F, Houston Joel F. Cengage Learning
